articles.headline: Instantly Yours, for a Fee
articles.snippet: Fear of Amazon.com has pushed a variety of stores to embrace delivery within hours as a must-have promotion, even though it’s costly and logistically complicated.
articles.abstract: Fear of Amazon.com has pushed a variety of stores to embrace delivery within hours as a must-have promotion, even though it’s costly and logistically complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ivy Wu did not immediately need the navy lace cocktail dress she ordered the other day. But when a representative from Shoptiques, an e-commerce site, arrived at her Midtown Manhattan office with the dress only hours after Ms. Wu, 26, had placed her order, “I was really impressed that it was here,” she said.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Car Factories Offer Hope for Spanish Industry and Workers
articles.snippet: With labor costs so low, Spain is attracting car manufacturers that see a large competitive advantage in producing there rather than in other European countries.
articles.abstract: With labor costs so low, Spain is attracting car manufacturers that see a large competitive advantage in producing there rather than in other European countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Despite the economic gloom that has enshrouded it since the onset of the global financial crisis, Spain has at least one industrial bright spot: The country and its skilled, if underemployed, work force have once again become a beacon for European carmakers.

articles.headline: Reading Pessimism in the Market for Bonds
articles.snippet: After a bull market in bonds that lasted about 30 years, a new bear market almost certainly has begun.
articles.abstract: After a bull market in bonds that lasted about 30 years, a new bear market almost certainly has begun.

articles.headline: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, U.S. Commander in Gulf War, Dies at 78
articles.snippet: General Schwarzkopf, who was lauded for his leadership during the war, was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, and Queen Elizabeth II made him an honorary knight.
articles.abstract: General Schwarzkopf, who was lauded for his leadership during the war, was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, and Queen Elizabeth II made him an honorary knight.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who commanded the American-led forces that crushed Iraq in the 1991 Persian Gulf war and became the nation’s most acclaimed military hero since the midcentury exploits of Generals Dwight D. Eisenhower and Douglas MacArthur, died on Thursday in Tampa, Fla. He was 78.

articles.headline: Developers of Wind Farms Run a Race Against the Calendar
articles.snippet: A federal subsidy for new installations will not apply to anything that goes online after Dec. 31, so the industry is rushing to complete projects now — and it expects to do little thereafter.
articles.abstract: A federal subsidy for new installations will not apply to anything that goes online after Dec. 31, so the industry is rushing to complete projects now — and it expects to do little thereafter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Forget about parties, resolutions or watching the ball drop. To Iberdrola Renewables, New Year’s Eve will mean checking on last-minute details like the data connections between 169 new wind turbines in New Hampshire, Massachusetts and California and its control center in Portland, Ore.

articles.headline: Summoned Back to Work, Senators Chafe at Inaction
articles.snippet: Lawmakers trudged back to Washington ostensibly to work out a deal to avoid large tax increases and spending cuts set to take effect in just a few days.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers trudged back to Washington ostensibly to work out a deal to avoid large tax increases and spending cuts set to take effect in just a few days.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senators bade hasty goodbyes to families, donned ties and pantsuits in lieu of sweat pants and Christmas sweaters and one by one returned to the Capitol on Thursday to begin the business of doing nothing in particular.

articles.headline: Islamists’ Harsh Justice Is on the Rise in North Mali
articles.snippet: Amputations have occurred at least 14 times since the Islamist takeover of the region last spring, with a vow of more to come.
articles.abstract: Amputations have occurred at least 14 times since the Islamist takeover of the region last spring, with a vow of more to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAMAKO, Mali — Moctar Touré was strapped to a chair, blindfolded, his right hand bound tight to the armrest with a rubber tube. A doctor came and administered a shot. Then Mr. Touré’s own brother wielded a knife, the kind used to slaughter sheep, and methodically carried out the sentence.

articles.headline: Sudden Death of Show Pony Clouds Image of Elite Pursuit
articles.snippet: In horse racing, industry leaders have taken significant steps against the overmedicating of horses. But in the cloistered equestrian world, the issue has attracted less notice.
articles.abstract: In horse racing, industry leaders have taken significant steps against the overmedicating of horses. But in the cloistered equestrian world, the issue has attracted less notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of May 26, Kristen Williams and her daughter, Katie, arrived at a barn on the grounds of the Devon Horse Show, where elite competitors in full dress have entertained spectators for the last century on Philadelphia’s Main Line.

articles.headline: Pearson to Take Stake in Nook Unit
articles.snippet: The British publishing and education company Pearson says it will invest $89.5 million in the digital Nook business for a 5 percent stake, as Barnes & Noble says that its holiday sales will be below expectations.
articles.abstract: The British publishing and education company Pearson says it will invest $89.5 million in the digital Nook business for a 5 percent stake, as Barnes & Noble says that its holiday sales will be below expectations.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Julia Werdigier
